column1: Jenks began in 1904 as a community site established by the Midland Valley Railroad between Tulsa and Muskogee
column2: alongside the Arkansas River. Though the river could only be utilized by shallow draft steamboats while the water level was up
column3: these two transportation routes proved vital to Jenks' early development.

column1: Jenks was named after William Henry Jenks the owner and director of the Midland Valley Railroad.  According to a 1957 article in the Tulsa Tribune
column2: an agent for the townsite company was told by the railroad home office to name a town for the director.The town was officially platted on July 15
column3: 1905. Also in 1905
column4: a major petroleum discovery was made
column5: further bolstering the economy of the area. The "Glenn Pool" oil well and subsequent oil claims brought many business people to the general area. In 1906
column6: many oil depots (also known as "tank farms") were constructed in Jenks. By the time of statehood

column2: tank farms were dismantled
column3: and agriculture became once again a major contributor to the Jenks economy. The economy of the area was further improved in the 1920s when many Bulgarian families immigrated to the area to farm. These immigrants established many vegetable farms.

column2: Jenks experienced many floods from the overflow of the Arkansas River and Polecat Creek. In the 1920s and 1930s floods were very severe.  During one flood in the late 1920s the water was so deep that it completely covered every building but the roof of the three-story-high school.  Everyone was evacuated except two men and one woman.  They had one shotgun
column3: one small boat
column4: food and a tent on top of the school.  They guarded the remains of Jenks for several weeks until the water receded.  In 1948
column5: the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers built a levee around Jenks
column6: and the community subsequently grew as a result of the increased safety and security. There was another threat of severe flooding in 1986
column7: when severe rainstorms upstream along the Arkansas River the Corps of Engineers to release as much as 300
column8: 000 cubic feet per second from the Keystone Dam into the river. This caused a mandatory evacuation order in Jenks and several other river communities.Jenks has served as a river crossing point via several bridges over the past century. In 1910
column9: a single-lane bridge was built and strengthened the economic success of the area. 1948 saw the construction of a replacement two-lane bridge which still stands today and now serves as a pedestrian crossing between the Riverwalk and the South Tulsa River Parks.  The original 1910 bridge was destroyed and all that is left are a few columns and pieces of metal that are seen when the water level is low. A four-lane bridge was built in 1996.

column1: Popular tourist draws include the Oklahoma Aquarium (the state's only freestanding aquarium) and Jenks’ downtown shops including boutiques
column2: restaurants
column3: and the Antiques and Arts District.

column1: Jenks was named the “Antique Capital of Oklahoma” by the former first lady of Oklahoma
column2: Shirley Bellmon
column3: and the many stores that call Main Street home keep that tradition going. Visitors can park and walk all day browsing vintage wares alongside new and repurposed offerings.

The Jenks School District is one of the largest in the state and encompasses significant portions of southwest Tulsa
column2: while many of the Jenks schools are located within the city of Tulsa.

column3: former President George W. Bush and Commerce Secretary Carlos Gutierrez announced Jenks Public Schools as a recipient of the 2005 Malcolm Baldrige National Quality Award
column4: the nation's highest Presidential honor for quality and organizational performance excellence.

column2: Richard Lloyd Jones Jr. Airport opened for business just outside Jenks. This airport is the official reliever for Tulsa International Airport and is one of the busiest in the state. It serves commercial and private air travel throughout the Tulsa area and has helped stimulate the growth of Jenks' economy.
